I should add, what's happening in the barrel is an extremely well controlled form of deflagration. The idea is not to release all of the energy in the powder at one time, because that would lead to very high pressures, quite possibly turning the breech or the barrel of the gun into shrapnel before the bullet/shot has time to accelerate and for the hot gases to expand a bit. (That's also exactly why detonation, especially with higher speed high explosives, is so "brisant", i.e. apt to cause fracturing in materials, and why lower speed high explosives like ANFO are better for mining work: often you don't want to just fracture everything into gravel, but to be pushed more gently into coarser rubble, without affecting the stability of the remaining rockbed.)

Instead we'd ideally like to have a burn which rapidly pushes the pressure inside the barrel to the engineering limit, then keeps it steady at that level right till when the bullet exits the barrel, and then suddenly stops developing any extra energy. That way we get the most velocity out of a given amount of propellant and barrel length, or vice versa minimize maximum recoil force, if lesser muzzle velocities suffice.

This flattening of the pressure profile is then actually what ammunition manufacturers try to achieve, via precisely controlling the grain geometry of the powder, via the composition of the primary propellant, and via the addition of various chemicals, some of which actually act as flame retardants in various phases of the burn. Also, this is why high end ammunition, especially for long range sniper fire, requires a careful match between the loading, the composition of the propellant, the bullet, and the gun itself: obviously the deflagration profile is going to affect recoil forces, any heat transfer to the barrel is going to minutely affect the details of the burn, caliper is going to affect the mechanical advantage between the inertia of the bullet and the expanding gases behind it, leading to varying exit velocity, there's wear to the barrel to consider, and who knows what else which could couple to the ballistics.

Since we're trying to get smarter every day, here, maybe Destin could return to the topic one day? I mean it's much more complicated than you'd think, and totally fascinating. Also, it's one of the main reasons ammunition manufacturers are very tight lipped about their secret sauce. I for instance have been trying to gather information about what goes into the Lapua .308 Magnum rounds for quite a while, to no avail.

Detonation: high explosives...grenades, dynamite, C4, bombs, missiles, etc...more blast than burn (higher "brisance")
Deflagration: low explosives...gasoline, gun powder, fireworks, etc...more rapid burn than blast...(higher "power")
If you replaced the gun powder in a bullet with C4, when you pulled the trigger it would explode in your hand and blow your wrist off. That's detonation, whereas in deflagration the powder burns up fast enough to build instant pressure and launch the projectile out of the barrel at high speed.

Are you sure of your terminology ? I have been an explosive Engineer for the last fourty years and I am certain that the propellent in any small arms cartridge does not deflagrate, it burns. The speed of the burn is controlled by the mix of the propellant the quality of the percussion cap and the degree of confinement. If you burn Small Arms Ammunition unconfined you will have the same rate of combustion until the case splits, after that the remaining propellent will burn much more slowly. Burning cartridges will typically send the projectile no more than a few meters. I burnt 1.2 million small arms cartridges  from .22inch to .50 calibre in a steel skip. None of the projectiles  went more than ten metres I investigated several bore deflagrations where the projectile containing a High Explosives has functioned in the bore of an Artillery Piece.  Generally HE Projectiles are a mix of RDX and TNT (Comp B).  When they function prematurely in the bore it is generally due to cracks in the fill or a micro deflagration caused by loose explosive dust in the fuze well. On set Back (the first dynamic force acting on the projectile) the fuze can apply sufficient force on the dust to detonate it. However, the detonation cannot be sustained sufficiently to propagate a full detonation and the projectile deflagrates in the bore. There are many examples of this effect on the internet. As an aside, when the projectile is manufactured the grain of the steel runs along the long axis. This was not a problem in early days as the propellant burnt less violently with a subsequently lower pressure. Modern propellants are faster burning and higher pressure. In early trials this led to the propellant progressing into the projectile cavity causing a deflagration. The solution was to weld a flat disk of steel with its steel grain at 90deg to the long axis. This is known as a "Slatter Base Plate". So burning, faster burning= Explosion. Deflagration ( where a detonating compound does not reach a full detonation) Detonating= a full detonation where the High Explosive reaches is full velocity of detonation (V of D). In layman terms.

A gun is not an example of a detonation. Like a firecracker, when a deflagration is somewhat contained it can produce  a bang, In the rare incidents where a detonation does take place in a gun, do to improper hand loading it results in a shattered firearm. Firecracker powder, or gunpowder if not contained will not bang when lit. fulmanate of mercury however when set off uncontained will bang. If you get a better definition of detonation and deflagration you will see that it mentions UNCONTAINED. Strangely enough the same substance can defligrate or detonate depending on conditions. For instance plastic explosives will deflagrate if lit with a match and detonate if set off with a detonator.

I subscribed to this channel, long ago and loved it. But today as I was researching about deflagration vs. detonation, I stumbled upon this video- "The FIRST episode of Smarter EveryDay." And I thought mann...Destin knows what we wanna know in science. :D #excitedagainforscience Go Destin.
The first smarter every day.  It is awesome.  :D

In detonation, a chemical reaction (we can safely call it "burning") is induced by the passing of a shock wave of sufficient speed and intensity through the explosive material. As the shock wave passes through it, the material promptly burns. Thus, a fast moving shock wave can make a lot of explosive go off very quickly--as quickly as the shock wave moves in that material (which is locally supersonic). In deflagration, the burning is induced when unburned material is raised to the temperature where it will ignite by the heat given off from the material that is already burning. In other words, deflagration is just regular old "burning." Set the edge of a a pile of kindling aflame and it spreads by deflagration.

The video is completely gummed up in that the ONLY proper "detonation" going on in the picture is that of the small amount of primary explosive in the the primer cap of each shotgun cartridge. Everything else shown, including the burning of the propellant that makes the bullet thingys come out of the gun thingy, is just plain old deflagration. Period.
There was no detonation in the chamber. It's a subsonic deflagration just like the burning flames. Smarter every day.

Gunpowder in open air deflagrates, yes. Put the same gunpowder in a contained environment, like the casing of a cartridge, and the pressure accelerates the speed of the burn. This is why the 5.56 NATO round can go from 0-3100 feet per second in only 20 inches of gun barrel.

if you guys are "rocket scientists", then you should know that gunpowder *deflagrates* it does not detonate. it burns at subsonic speeds unlike TNT which detonates.

from what i've heard detonation occurs when events happen at supersonic speeds, or faster than sound, such as tnt, but deflagration would be subsonic, slower and more controlled explosion or event, with the likelihood for data outliers substantially reduced. for example, one has a higher chance for a bullet to swerve off course with detonation due to uncontrollable atmospheric conditions with the vacuum behind the bullet being ruptured, while subsonic ammo would stay more on course.

But they really are not nearly as energetic as a typical explosive decomposition, which is an entirely different reaction. Fuel/oxidizer mixtures can be made to break the sound barrier by increasing confinement so they are forced to reach a higher pressure before the walls burst, whereas decompositions that I consider to be real detonations are hardly effected at all by confinement, and have a predictable rate of detonation that will occur as according to the density of the explosive itself.

There's actually a fair deal of dispute about what a detonation is compared to a deflagration. One point of view is that anything that expands faster than the rate of sound is a detonation, the view you present. The other point of view is that nothing should be considered a detonation unless it is an explosive decomposition of a molecule, not merely an oxidized fuel able to burn quickly enough to break the sound barrier. Some fuel and oxidizer combinations will break the threshold (continued)

If the reaction in your gun were a detonation, the barrel would be ripped apart ;-) Those are both deflagrations... detonation is pressure-moderated and occurs above the speed of sound in the energetic matertial. Deflagration is temperature moderated and occurs below the speed of sound.
You just want enough pressure to be generated in your gun, that's why the propellant is designed to deflagrate. Black Powder for example can't be driven to a detoantion, even if it gives a big boom ;-)

Looking forward to the series!  Not to geek out too much but the smokeless powder in the cartridge is oxidizing (deflagrating) rather than explosively decomposing (detonating).  There is speculation that a light charge in a large chamber can cause the powder to detonate (so called 'light load detonation'), but these can damage the gun.

The primer, on the other hand, is detonating.  And so would a half pound of Tannerite, if you should so equip yourselves.  (Would LOVE to see that at 100k fps :)

@chumgrinder25 The white letters were written with chalk (pause at 0:14).  The welder then traced the chalk lines with a MIG welder.  The MIG 'gun' (pause at 0:16) is hollow and has a thin welding wire being constantly fed from it.  This wire feeds new metal into the welding process and creates a bead of metal just like a tube of white hot toothpaste.  This bead is the bright purplish/whitish lines in the 'new' letters.  The black on either side is the soot from the flux core of the weld wire.
